claims.claim: Incarceration can lead to a transformative perspective on life and societal roles.
claims.quote: If I didn't go to prison, none of this would not have came to fruition. I would've still been in somebody's kitchen cooking something, but it took me to go in there to come back out and look at the world different eyes...

claims.claim: Awareness and participation in voting can significantly increase among formerly incarcerated individuals with proper information.
claims.quote: We need to inform people coming home. They need to learn that they had the right to vote. And then, The more we tell people they had a right to vote.

claims.claim: Many formerly incarcerated individuals are not aware of their voting rights.
claims.quote: they like, you know, I got a felony, I can't vote. I said, I got one too, but I've been voting since I got out.

claims.claim: Local voting can directly impact the community environment and resource availability.
claims.quote: the suburbs voting for all of that and we not voting. So of course they gonna close everything around us and wanna know why we don't have it.

claims.claim: Misconceptions about the value of one's vote can deter participation in the democratic process.
claims.quote: And they was like, well my vote don't count.

claims.claim: Reentry into society offers an opportunity to engage in social and political activism.
claims.quote: Voting Access for All was, was, was a great, great opportunity for me to help found.

claims.claim: Experiencing the consequences of judicial decisions motivates formerly incarcerated individuals to participate in voting.
claims.quote: If you had a prosecutor or if you had a judge, you know, you could vote them outta the seat 'cause they didn't put you in jail.
